awd_titl_txt: Optimizing Environmental Perfluoroalkyl Acid Degradation by Elucidating Mechanisms: A Coupled Computational and Experimental Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation.  Prof. Professor Shubham Vyas and his students investigate the mechanisms by which perfluoroalkyl acids (PFAAs) are transformed in the environment. PFAAs are synthetic chemicals that are used as coating for carpets, textiles and paper, and fire extinguishing foams. Because PFAAs are very unreactive chemicals, they are extremely persistent compounds in the environment. They also pose threats to human and ecological health, for instance as pollutants in drinking water. The overall goal of this project is to test various chemical conditions in which one can improve the destruction of PFAAs in aqueous environment. At the same time, the energy demand for such a process should be reduced. Several undergraduate and graduate students are getting trained during this project as they engage in multidisciplinary research in environmental chemistry. Furthermore, the investigators actively use research strategies and findings from this project to reach out to K-12 students and educators.

Professor Vyas and his team employ a coupled experimental and computational approach to carry out this project. They use two representative PFAAs, perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctanesulfonate (PFOS). Chemical computations using density functional theory and post-Hartree-Fock-based calculations provide guidance for experimental efforts. The experiments iteratively feed findings back into the chemical computations. This improves the models and explains unusual experimental findings. The Vyas lab studies the degradation of PFAAs using superoxide radical anion, hydroxyl radical, and persulfate radical anion in the presence of transition metal cations. These reactions are likely facilitated by heat or by external light. Time-resolved absorption spectroscopic measurements provide information on reactive intermediates and the efficiency of light triggered reactions. Mass spectrometric and chromatographic measurements are used to monitor reaction products. Students participating in this inherently interdisciplinary research project acquire a unique skill set that incorporates elements of computational and experimental environmental chemistry, providing them with skills for their future careers. This project is also used as a vehicle to incorporate concepts of environmental computational chemistry into undergraduate and graduate chemistry curricula.

por.por_cntn:
This project was funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation to investigate the chemical mechanisms of the oxidative degradation of perfluoroalkyl acids (PFAAs). PFAAs are part of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs), which are manmade chemicals used in several applications such as in aqueous film-forming firefighting foams (AFFF) and in coatings for carpets, textiles, and paper. Since PFAAs are extremely stable, and chemically and thermally inert, they accumulate in environmental matrices leading to aquatic life and human exposures. The toxicity of PFAS to humans and other life forms has been reported in several prior studies.  

This project investigated many fundamental aspects of PFAAs such as their reactivity and properties.

Pefluoroalkyl chains of PFAA adopt helical conformations which are dramatically different than their hydrogenated analogs. This was probed using accurate chemical computations. Moreover, a computational protocol was prepared to accurately predict 19-F nuclear magnetic resonance shifts of PFASs, which will help in predicting what PFASs are available in a mixture. This is particularly important given that we do not have standards for the majority of PFASs that are in circulation. Two journal articles were published based on these results.

In terms of reactivity, it was debated for a long time that sulfate radical, a reactive species, can only degrade perfluoroalkyl carboxylic acids (PFCAs) at extremely acidic conditions. Using nanosecond laser spectroscopy, this project directly measured the reactivity of PFCAs at a variety of acidic conditions to conclude that reactivity of PFCAs with sulfate radical is not impacted within mild to strong acidic conditions. This outcome helps explain several previous reports which have measured such PFCA reactivity using indirect means and highlights the impact of other species available in the experiments. These results were summarized in a journal article and the research was featured on the front cover of the journal.

Several reports during the tenure of this project reported using electron transfer theory along with quantum chemical computations to predict the oxidation of PFCAs. However, they did not consider the role of water molecules surrounding the sulfate radical, which results in inaccurate results. This project also carried out extensive computations to predict properties of sulfate radical and the impact of including water molecules around the sulfate radical. It was concluded that more than 10 water molecules should be included in doing computations with sulfate radical. While investigating the mechanisms involved in oxidative degradation of PFAAs, the project also found an unexplored mechanism which is 1,2-fluorine atom shifts. Such a mechanism can result in several isomers of the products resulting in problems with fluorine mass balance. Two journal articles were published based on these findings.

While this project intended to focus only on the oxidative degradation of PFAAs, due to the nature of chemical computations involved in the project, reductive degradation of PFAAs were also investigated. Preliminary work on reductive degradation that shows the loss of fluoride anion upon reduction depends on C-F bond dissociation energy was published collaboratively with other researchers. However, a more robust computational protocol was developed which can accurately predict the reduction potential of PFAAs and explained the experimental findings that PFCAs and perfluoroalkyl sulfonates (PFSA) degradation has different chain length dependence. This work was also featured on the journal cover and won the ACS Editor’s Choice Award.

Findings from this project were presented at several invited talks at several universities and conferences (both national and international). Furthermore, several conference contributions were made using the results of this project which helped with the professional development of graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project. Further in terms of workforce development, the project supported 5 graduate (fully and partially) and several undergraduate students. These graduate students are now employed at national research facilities or at industries, and undergraduate students are either employed or pursuing graduate degrees.

Different bits of the project were also implemented in three different undergraduate and graduate courses taught by the principal investigator (PI). PI also consistently participated in the summer camp for dyslexic kids where PI and several students involved in this project spent a day with (K-6) kids every year. This camp hosts kids from all over the country.

The project findings also laid the grounds for several new research grants, for example, CHE-1807739 and CHE-2109210.

In sum, the research work from this project revealed some very critical aspects of PFAS reactivity and properties which resulted in several journal articles. Many graduate and undergraduate students benefited by doing research involved in this project. The findings of this project were also implemented in different courses and resulted in new research avenues.
